content.webTitle: Budget tax cut: religious groups urge those earning more than $80,000 to donate $6 gain to charity

fields.headline: Budget tax cut: religious groups urge those earning more than $80,000 to donate $6 gain to charity
fields.bodyText: Two young Australians, representing a Muslim and a Christian organisation, have joined forces to call on people who earn $80,000 who got the $6 tax cut in the last budget to donate it to charity. Fahim Khondaker, of the Islamic Council of Queensland, and Brad Chilcott, of the Activate church, have set up a pledge website where donors can pledge their $6 tax cut every week to one of 10 high-profile charities. “If you earn over $80,000 you just got a tax cut of $6/week,” the website says. “75% of Australians miss out on this, including millions of Australians for whom $6 can make a big difference. “Rather than buying an extra coffee or two, many of us would prefer that our tax cuts helped people who could really use it.” Khondaker said they had come up with the idea after listening to people suggesting the tax cuts were unfair but individually would not amount to much. “I wanted a platform where people could do something tangible rather than just talk about it,” he said. “We know that philanthropy is no replacement for a fair tax system – and so want to make it possible for like-minded Australians to help make our nation fairer. “If you’re a person who’ll benefit from these changes and believe that money would achieve more if it were spent empowering people at the other end of the income spectrum – helping people with disabilities find stable employment, providing support for vulnerable young people and serving victims of family and domestic violence – we’re inviting you to share your tax cut for the sake of Australia’s future.” The website is simply a pledge system, which will record the pledge and then direct the donor to one of 10 nominated charities. Week after week, the amounts will be aggregated and reported.
